description: From Middle English festival (adjective), from Old French festival (“festive”), from Late Latin fēstīvālis, from Latin fēstīvus (“festive”). Displaced native Old English frēols. The noun is shortened from festival day, from Middle English festival dai, festiuall day (“feast day, festival”).

adjectives.description: festival (comparative more festival, superlative most festival)

entries.meaning: Pertaining to a feast or feast day; festive. (Now only as the noun used attributively.)
An event or series of special events centred on the celebration or promotion of some theme or aspect of the community, often held at regular intervals.
examples: The Reading and Leeds festivals take place on the August bank holiday.
A Welsh eisteddfod is a literary festival.

entries.meaning: In mythology, a set of celebrations in the honour of a god.
